thread.title: Cats pay price of Selwood’s speeding ticket
thread.title_full: Cats pay price of Selwood’s speeding ticket

title: Cats pay price of Selwood’s speeding ticket
text:
The TAC and Geelong end their 11-year partnership after Joel Selwood lost his licence for speeding March 7, 2017 5:58pm by Staff Writers Source: FOX SPORTS GEELONG captain Joel Selwood’s recent speeding ticket has come at a cost, with the Cats and the Transport Accident Commission (TAC) parting ways. 
The TAC and Geelong released a joint statement confirming the 11-year partnership would not be renewed. 
Selwood lost his licence for a month after being caught travelling at 127km/hour in a 100km/hour zone in February. 
In the statement, the TAC said “in January 2015 the GFC stated publicly that in the event of any further serious incidents the partnership would be relinquished, and the TAC respects the club’s integrity.” 
Speaking on SEN, Geelong chief executive Brian Cook said the TAC lost “a lot of patience” after seven incidents in 10 years. Cockatoo cleared of KO tackle 0:17 
“I think seven incidents in 10 years, they did lose a lot of patience and understandably have indicated that we’ve agreed that the relationship won’t continue in this current form or previous form into the future,” Cook said. 
“The last incident (was) in January 2015 with Dawson Simpson and we promised at that stage that if there was a major incident after that then we would pull out — and pretty much that is what has happened. 
Cook said by the TAC’s standards, the Selwood speeding situation counted as a major incident. 
“He was certainly speeding,” Cook said. 
“In their own policies within the TAC if there was any executive who did the same thing, there’s an automatic redundancy made or dismissal. 
“So they’re treating Joel as an executive, so to speak, within their own rules and regulations. I think they’re being reasonable. 
“It’s just difficult to manage a contract like this. We’ve done our best and in the end it hasn’t worked.” View All Comments The latest sports news, in your inbox daily. Email
